section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children with a name game, and introduce vocabulary (cactus, desert)
Begin Story Time by asking, Why does nobody want to hug Hank the cactus?
Read for enjoyment, counting out the characters in the story as you read.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence.
Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set when objects are arranged (up to 10) in a line, a rectangular array, in a circle, or (up to 5) scattered (Cardinality).
Identify emotions in self.
Understand and use varied types of words.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Challenge children to count the characters.
Guide children to identify the number of animals that stop by.
Help children recognize that the last number they say is how many.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do we talk about and manage our feelings?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What book did you choose? Why did you choose that one?
Pretend that you are happy. What is making you happy? What do you do when you are happy?
Grab a group of buttons. How many buttons are there?
Write about someone who came to visit you. How did you spend your time together?
Make a happy poster. What colors will you use? Why?
What letter did you make? How did you make it?
What are you building? How many blocks have you used so far?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the mind builder understand and manage your feelings and introduce vocabulary. (feelings, prickly).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Nobody Hugs a Cactus.
Read closely to notice and talk about understanding and managing feelings.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence.
Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set when objects are arranged (up to 10) in a line, a rectangular array, in a circle, or (up to 5) scattered (Cardinality).
Identify emotions in self.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Verbally share the meaning of their own writing.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to share cubes with a partner.
Challenge children to count the number of cubes given. Then have children swap roles.
Have children discuss emotions when sharing.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do we talk about and manage our feelings?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How does the character in that book show her feelings?
Can you act like you’re surprised? What surprised you?
Make a group of three counters. How can you check that there are three in all?
Have you ever seen a desert? Can you write about one?
Draw a picture that shows someone feeling angry.
Trace the word feelings. What letters do you see?
Why did you use those materials to build that?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to practice counting, engage children with a physical activity, and introduce vocabulary (peaceful, relax).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Nobody Hugs a Cactus and asking the guiding question, Why did Hank change his mind about wanting to live alone?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence.
Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set when objects are arranged (up to 10) in a line, a rectangular array, in a circle, or (up to 5) scattered (Cardinality).
Identify emotions in self.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Express an opinion.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to take a set number of Connecting Cubes representing desert plants out of a bag.
Challenge children to count out the number of cubes and make sure they have the correct total.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do we talk about and manage our feelings?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How do the characters in that book manage their feelings?
How could you pretend to be happy? Sad? Angry?
Can you make two groups of different objects? How many are in each group? How many in all?
Describe how you would take care of a cactus like Hank.
Can you draw an angry face? Why does that face look angry?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of sad?
How did you choose what to build? How did you choose what to make it with?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Nobody Hugs a Cactus by Carter Goodrich. Copyright © 2019 by Carter Goodrich. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Simon & Schuster Children’s Publishing Division, a division of Simon & Schuster, Inc.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: If You’re Happy and You Know It

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about feelings, engage children with dance, and introduce vocabulary (scared, surprised).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts If You’re Happy and You Know It and Nobody Hugs a Cactus.
Read interactively and connect to managing emotions and counting.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence.
Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set when objects are arranged (up to 10) in a line, a rectangular array, in a circle, or (up to 5) scattered (Cardinality).
Identify emotions in self.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Express an opinion.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Count a number of cubes behind a “curtain” and ask children to match that number of cubes on their side of the curtain.
Count cubes on both sides to check for the same number of cubes.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do we talk about and manage our feelings?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How do you feel about this story?
Pretend to be one of Hank’s friends in the desert. Why did you choose that friend?
Make two patterns and compare them. Which is longer?
Choose an emotion. Write about a time that you felt it.
Draw to show the difference between scared and surprised.
What sound do you hear at the beginning of cactus? Can you draw that letter?
How can you make what you are building bigger?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Nobody Hugs a Cactus by Carter Goodrich. Copyright © 2019 by Carter Goodrich. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Simon & Schuster Children’s Publishing Division, a division of Simon & Schuster, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photo © Dan Kosmayer/Shutterstock.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to practice identifying numbers and introduce vocabulary (lonely).
Start Story Time by revisiting Nobody Hugs a Cactus and asking, What would you tell Hank to help him manage his feelings?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and a focus on emotions.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence.
Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set when objects are arranged (up to 10) in a line, a rectangular array, in a circle, or (up to 5) scattered (Cardinality).
Identify emotions in self.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Compose an informative text.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: How do you manage your feelings?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do we talk about and manage our feelings?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What kind of book do you want to read next?
Pretend to be an animal in the desert. What will you be? How will you act?
Use counters to represent groups of friends. How many friends are in each group?
What story can you tell about someone who feels calm?
Can you draw a new friend for a cactus? What will it look like?
Can you count the number of letters in your name?
What did you build? How many blocks did you use?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Count 1–10 items, with one count per item.
Count up to 10 items and demonstrate that the last count indicates how many items were counted.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/feelings and behaviors.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Count 1–10 items, with one count per item.
Count up to 10 items and demonstrate that the last count indicates how many items were counted.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/feelings and behaviors.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Count 1–10 items, with one count per item.
Count up to 10 items and demonstrate that the last count indicates how many items were counted.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/feelings and behaviors.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Count 1–10 items, with one count per item.
Count up to 10 items and demonstrate that the last count indicates how many items were counted.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/feelings and behaviors.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Count 1–10 items, with one count per item.
Count up to 10 items and demonstrate that the last count indicates how many items were counted.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/feelings and behaviors.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
